---
title: "WAAM: Metal 3D Printing"
sidebar: science
---

> **TL;DR**
>
> - **Technology:** Wire Arc Additive Manufacturing (wire deposition by arc)
> - **Material:** Wire 1.6-2.0 mm diameter (Al, Fe from rolling mill)
> - **Productivity:** ~60-180 kg/day (3 cells) for complex parts
> - **Application:** Robot bodies, brackets, frames, tooling

---

## Overview

WAAM is a metal 3D printing technology where a robotic arm melts wire with an electric arc and deposits material layer by layer. It is an industrial alternative to powder-based 3D printing, faster and more economical.

---

## Operating Principle

```{mermaid}
flowchart TD
    subgraph INPUT["INPUT"]
        WIRE["Wire 1.6 mm diameter<br/>from drawing line"]
    end

    subgraph WAAM_CELL["WAAM CELL"]
        ROBOT["6-axis robot"]
        TORCH["Welding torch"]
        ARC["Electric arc<br/>~5000C"]
        ARGON["Shielding gas Ar"]
        TABLE["Rotary table"]
    end

    subgraph POST["POST-PROCESSING"]
        CNC["5-axis CNC<br/>milling"]
        FINISH["Finishing"]
    end

    subgraph OUTPUT["OUTPUT"]
        PARTS["Finished parts<br/>bodies, frames, brackets"]
    end

    WIRE --> ROBOT
    ROBOT --> TORCH
    TORCH --> ARC
    ARGON --> ARC
    ARC --> TABLE
    TABLE --> CNC
    CNC --> FINISH
    FINISH --> PARTS

    style INPUT fill:#f0e68c
    style WAAM_CELL fill:#fff3cd
    style POST fill:#d4edda
    style OUTPUT fill:#cce5ff
```

**Process:**
1. Robot feeds wire to the torch
2. Electric arc melts the wire (and workpiece surface)
3. Molten droplet solidifies, forming deposited layer
4. Robot moves 1-2 mm, deposits next layer
5. Layer by layer the part grows

---

## WAAM Cell

### Robotic Arm

| Parameter | Value |
|-----------|-------|
| Type | 6-axis industrial robot |
| Payload | 10-20 kg (torch + wire) |
| Positioning accuracy | +/-0.1 mm |
| Travel speed | 0.5-2 m/s |
| Material | Steel Fe + Al (local production) |

**Difference from Earth robots:** Lightweight Al construction (low gravity 0.38g), no lubrication (operates in 0.1 atm nitrogen).

---

### Welding Torch

| Parameter | Value |
|-----------|-------|
| Type | MIG/MAG (Metal Inert Gas) |
| Current | 150-300 A |
| Voltage | 20-30 V |
| Power | 3-9 kW |
| Wire feed | 3-8 m/min |
| Shielding gas | Argon (Ar) - from Earth |

**Why argon?**
- Inert gas - does not react with melt
- Heavier than air - displaces nitrogen from welding zone
- Prevents oxidation and porosity

**Argon consumption:** ~10 L/min (200 cubic meters/month per cell) - critical import from Earth

---

### Rotary Table

| Parameter | Value |
|-----------|-------|
| Diameter | 1-2 m |
| Load capacity | 500-1000 kg |
| Rotation speed | 0.1-10 rpm |
| Tilt | +/-45 degrees |

**Purpose:** Allows robot to deposit complex parts by rotating them to optimal angles.

---

## Materials for WAAM

| Material | Application | Productivity |
|----------|-------------|--------------|
| Aluminum (Al) | Robot bodies, brackets | ~3 t/day |
| Iron (Fe) | Frames, structural elements | ~1 t/day |

**Wire source:** [Rolling mill](rolling.qmd) (drawing line)

---

## Productivity

| Parameter | Value |
|-----------|-------|
| Deposition rate | 1-3 kg/hour per cell |
| Number of WAAM cells | 3 (per factory) |
| Operation | 20 hours/day |
| **TOTAL** | **~20-60 kg/day per cell** |
| **For 3 cells** | **~60-180 kg/day** |

**Why not more?**
- WAAM is slower than casting but allows complex shapes without tooling
- Used for parts that cannot be cast (hollow bodies, complex geometries)

---

## Post-Processing: CNC Milling

After WAAM, the part has a rough surface and excess material. Finish machining is required.

### 5-Axis Machining Center

| Parameter | Value |
|-----------|-------|
| Type | Vertical machining center |
| Number of axes | 5 (X, Y, Z + 2 rotary) |
| Spindle power | 10-20 kW |
| Spindle speed | 10000-20000 rpm |
| Tool | Carbide end mills (WC - from Earth) |

**Coolant (cutting fluid):**
- Oil in closed loop (recirculation)
- Filtration through centrifuge
- Cooling on radiators outside dome

**Machining accuracy:** +/-0.05 mm

## Typical Parts Produced by WAAM

| Part | Material | Mass | Print time | Application |
|------|----------|------|------------|-------------|
| Crab-M body | Al | 50 kg | 20 hours | [Crab-M robot](../../robots/assembly/crabs.qmd) |
| Centaur-M frame | Al | 30 kg | 12 hours | [Centaur-M robot](../../robots/assembly/centaurs.qmd) |
| Caster brackets | Fe | 20 kg | 8 hours | [Continuous casting](casting.qmd) |
| Assembly tooling | Fe | 10 kg | 5 hours | Jigs, fixtures |

---

## Advantages of WAAM

| Advantage | Description |
|-----------|-------------|
| No tooling | No molds, dies, casting patterns needed |
| Rapid prototyping | New part in 1 day (casting takes weeks) |
| Material savings | Only required metal used (casting has 30-50% waste) |
| Complex geometry | Cavities, internal channels, organic shapes |

---

## WAAM Limitations

| Limitation | Solution |
|------------|----------|
| Low speed | Use for complex parts, simple ones by casting |
| Surface roughness | Post-processing on CNC |
| Argon import | Critical consumable - shipped from Earth |
| Tool wear | Carbide tools (WC) - import |

---

## Energy Consumption

| Component | Power | Quantity | TOTAL |
|-----------|-------|----------|-------|
| WAAM cell (robot + torch) | 10 kW | 3 | 30 kW |
| CNC machining center | 20 kW | 2 | 40 kW |
| Exhaust ventilation | 5 kW | 1 | 5 kW |
| Automation | 5 kW | - | 5 kW |
| **TOTAL** | | | **~80 kW** |

## Maintenance

| Operation | Frequency | Performed by |
|-----------|-----------|--------------|
| Torch replacement | 1 month | Centaur-M |
| CNC tool replacement | 1 week | Centaur-M |
| Rotary table cleaning | Daily | Crab-M |
| Robot calibration | Weekly | Automation |
| Coolant oil refill | Weekly | Centaur-M |

---

## Quality Control

| Parameter | Control method | Standard | Action on deviation |
|-----------|---------------|----------|---------------------|
| Porosity | Ultrasonic | <2% | Reject |
| Dimensions | 3D laser scanner | +/-0.1 mm | Rework on CNC |
| Cracks | Dye penetrant inspection | No cracks | Reject |
| Hardness | Hardness tester | Per specification | Heat treatment |
